Armed reprex, next step figure ask. ’s question: start community.rstudio.com, /StackOverflow. people answer questions. ’s bug: ’re right place, file issue. ’re sure: let community help figure ! problem bug feature request, can easily return report . opening new issue, sure search issues pull requests make sure bug hasn’t reported /already fixed development version. default, search pre-populated :issue :open. can edit qualifiers (e.g. :pr, :closed) needed. example, ’d simply remove :open search issues repo, open closed. right place, need file issue, please review “File issues” paragraph tidyverse contributing guidelines. Thanks help!

title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: FASSTER (Forecasting Additive Switching Seasonality, Trend Exogenous Regressors) state space model designed forecasting time series complex multiple seasonality patterns. model addresses common limitations existing approaches providing: Flexibility: Modular specification trend, seasonality, ARMA components State switching: Different seasonal patterns different categories (e.g., weekdays vs. weekends) Exogenous regressors: Natural support external variables Speed: Efficient estimation using Kalman filter Decomposition: Model-based decomposition reveals underlying patterns

title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: FASSTER particularly useful time series : Multiple seasonal patterns change based categories conditions Irregular switching patterns (e.g., working days vs. holidays) High-frequency data traditional methods slow Missing values need handled gracefully External predictors influence time series Common applications include: Pedestrian traffic counts (weekday/weekend patterns) Energy demand (day/night seasonal patterns) Retail sales (teaching periods, holidays) Web traffic (different patterns day type)

title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: FASSTER uses formula-based interface similar R’s lm():
code: FASSTER(y ~ model_components)

title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: Use poly() specify polynomial trends: poly(1) - constant level poly(2) - linear trend poly(n) - polynomial order n

title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: Two types seasonality available: season(period) - seasonal factors fourier(period, harmonics) - Fourier terms example: - season("year") - annual seasonal factors - fourier("day") - daily seasonality Fourier terms - fourier("day", K = 6) - daily Fourier seasonality 6 harmonics

title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: Include autoregressive moving average terms: ARMA(p, q) - ARMA model p AR terms q MA terms

title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: Include external variables using standard formula notation: x1 + x2 - add regressors log(x1) - transformations

title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: key innovation FASSTER switching operator %S%, allows different model components different categories: creates separate states level group. example: Switching can nested complex patterns:
code: FASSTER(y ~ group %S% model_components) # Different hourly patterns for weekdays vs. weekends FASSTER(Count ~ day_type %S% fourier(24)) # Different models for different day types and weather conditions FASSTER(y ~ day_type %S% (trend(1) + weather %S% fourier(24)))

what: Example: Gas production with structural break
title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: Let’s demonstrate FASSTER using quarterly gas production data.
code: library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(lubridate) #>  #> Attaching package: 'lubridate' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     date, intersect, setdiff, union  # Use Australian gas production data gas_data <- tsibbledata::aus_production |>   select(Quarter, Gas) |>   filter(!is.na(Gas))  # Split into training and test sets train <- gas_data |> filter(year(Quarter) < 2008) test <- gas_data |> filter(year(Quarter) >= 2008)

previous_headings: Example: Gas production with structural break
title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: simple model switching trend capture structural break occurred around 1970: model includes: log(Gas) - log transformation regularise data’s variation trend(2) - separate level trend switched 1970 fourier("year") - annual seasonal pattern Fourier terms
code: # Fit model with pre/post 1970 trends fit <- train |>   model(     fasster = FASSTER(log(Gas) ~ (year(Quarter) < 1970) %S% trend(2) + fourier("year"))   )  fit #> # A mable: 1 x 1 #>     fasster #>     <model> #> 1 <FASSTER>

previous_headings: Example: Gas production with structural break
title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: FASSTER provides model-based decomposition time series components:  decomposition reveals: - Original data fitted values - Level components (separate pre/post 1970) - Seasonal components Notice pre-1970 level remains flat 1970, post-1970 level takes , highlighting structural break.
code: components(fit) #> # A dable: 208 x 6 [1Q] #> # Key:     .model [1] #> # :        log(Gas) = `(year(Quarter) < 1970)_TRUE/trend(2)` + `(year(Quarter) #> #   < 1970)_FALSE/trend(2)` + `fourier("year")` #>    .model  Quarter `log(Gas)` (year(Quarter) < 1970)_TR…¹ (year(Quarter) < 197…² #>    <chr>     <qtr>      <dbl>                       <dbl>                  <dbl> #>  1 fasster 1956 Q1       1.61                        1.75                  -4.43 #>  2 fasster 1956 Q2       1.79                        1.78                  -4.31 #>  3 fasster 1956 Q3       1.95                        1.68                  -4.19 #>  4 fasster 1956 Q4       1.79                        1.77                  -4.24 #>  5 fasster 1957 Q1       1.61                        1.86                  -4.43 #>  6 fasster 1957 Q2       1.95                        1.79                  -3.34 #>  7 fasster 1957 Q3       1.95                        1.88                  -3.22 #>  8 fasster 1957 Q4       1.79                        1.85                  -3.23 #>  9 fasster 1958 Q1       1.61                        1.84                  -3.15 #> 10 fasster 1958 Q2       1.95                        1.82                  -2.81 #> # ℹ 198 more rows #> # ℹ abbreviated names: ¹​`(year(Quarter) < 1970)_TRUE/trend(2)`, #> #   ²​`(year(Quarter) < 1970)_FALSE/trend(2)` #> # ℹ 1 more variable: `fourier("year")` <dbl>  # Plot decomposition components(fit) |>    autoplot()

previous_headings: Example: Gas production with structural break
title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: Generate forecasts using fitted model:  forecasts: - Use post-1970 pattern future predictions - Include uncertainty intervals grow time - Capture trend seasonal patterns learned data
code: # Forecast test period fc <- forecast(fit, h = "5 years")  # Plot forecasts autoplot(fc, train)

title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: FASSTER handles missing values naturally estimation. Kalman filter simply skips updating states data missing:
code: # Model works even with missing values data_with_na <- gas_data |>   # Insert some missing values randomly   mutate(Gas = if_else(row_number() %in% sample(n(), 10), NA_real_, Gas))  fit_na <- data_with_na |>   model(FASSTER(Gas ~ (year(Quarter) < 1970) %S% trend(2) + fourier("year", K = 2)))  # Interpolate missing values fit_na |>    interpolate(data_with_na) #> # A tsibble: 218 x 2 [1Q] #>    Quarter   Gas #>      <qtr> <dbl> #>  1 1956 Q1   5   #>  2 1956 Q2   6   #>  3 1956 Q3  23.6 #>  4 1956 Q4   6   #>  5 1957 Q1   5   #>  6 1957 Q2   7   #>  7 1957 Q3  22.1 #>  8 1957 Q4   6   #>  9 1958 Q1   5   #> 10 1958 Q2   7   #> # ℹ 208 more rows

title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: Create complex models nested switching:
code: # Different patterns for working days and rainy days FASSTER(y ~ workday %S% (trend(1) + rain %S% fourier("day")))

title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: Mix grouped ungrouped components:
code: # Shared trend, separate seasonality FASSTER(y ~ poly(2) + workday %S% fourier("day"))

title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: Correct remaining autocorrelation:
code: # Add AR(1) term FASSTER(y ~ workday %S% (poly(1) + fourier("day")) + ARMA(ar = c(0.8, -0.3), ma = 0.4))

title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: FASSTER uses heuristic approach fast parameter estimation: Filter data default parameters Smooth states approximate desired behavior Extract variances smoothed states Use estimated parameters final model “filterSmooth” approach: - Requires two passes data - Works well non-saturating Fourier terms - Provides reasonable estimates without maximum likelihood long series, estimation can sped using recent data:
code: # Use only last 1000 observations for parameter estimation FASSTER(y ~ model, include = 1000)

title: Introduction to FASSTER
text: FASSTER provides flexible framework modeling complex time series : Modular component specification State switching irregular multiple seasonality Fast estimation via Kalman filtering Natural handling missing values Model-based decomposition concise formula interface makes easy specify models suitable high-frequency data complex seasonal patterns.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Mitchell O'Hara-Wild. Author, maintainer. Rob Hyndman. Author, thesis advisor.

title: Authors and Citation
text: O'Hara-Wild M, Hyndman R (2026). fasster: Fast Additive Switching Seasonality, Trend, Exogenous Regressors. R package version 0.2.0, https://github.com/tidyverts/fasster.

what: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend, and Exogenous Regressors
title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend, and Exogenous Regressors
text: implementation FASSTER (Forecasting Additive Switching Seasonality, Trend Exogenous Regressors) model R. model designed capture patterns multiple seasonality state space framework using state switching. fasster package prioritizes flexibility, computational speed accuracy provide convenient tools modelling, predicting understanding high frequency time-series.

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend, and Exogenous Regressors
text: model developed 2017 honours thesis, clearest description examples using fasster can found useR! 2018 talk: slides, video, source. model uses forward filtering backward smoothing heuristic estimating initial states model. essentially opinionated wrapper {dlm} package aimed making easier specify sophisticated model suitable forecasting complex seasonal patterns.

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend, and Exogenous Regressors
text: stable version can installed CRAN: development version can installed GitHub using:
code: install.packages("fasster") # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("tidyverts/fasster")

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend, and Exogenous Regressors
text: fasster allows flexible model specification allowing user specify model structure standard formula conventions. Commonly used state space components can added using following convenience functions: trend(n) include n-th order polynomial season(s) include seasonal factor frequency s fourier(s, q) include seasonal fourier terms frequency s q harmonics arma(ar, ma) include ARMA term (ar ma vectors coefficients) Exogenous regressors can added referring name example, create model trend monthly seasonality, can use: interface creating FASSTER model introduces new formula construct, %S%, known switch operator. allows modelling complex patterns multiple seasonality modelling components group separately switching .
code: library(fasster) library(tidyverse) library(lubridate) library(tsibble) library(fable)  lung_deaths <- as_tsibble(cbind(mdeaths, fdeaths), pivot_longer = FALSE) fit <- lung_deaths |>   model(fasster = FASSTER(fdeaths ~ mdeaths)) fit |> report() #> Series: fdeaths  #> Model: FASSTER  #>  #> Estimated variances: #>  State noise variances (W): #>   mdeaths #>    1.7119e-34 #>  #>  Observation noise variance (V): #>   1.6631e+03 #>  #> Initial states (m0): #>   mdeaths: 3.7711e-01 fit <- as_tsibble(USAccDeaths) |>    model(fasster = FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12))) fit |> report() #> Series: value  #> Model: FASSTER  #>  #> Estimated variances: #>  State noise variances (W): #>   fourier(12) #>    3.5590e-13 2.3103e-13 3.5905e-13 4.3745e-13 3.6531e-13 8.4136e-13 2.6433e-13 3.4998e-13 4.1144e-13 3.6736e-13 1.3359e-13 #>   trend(1) #>    5.9382e+03 #>  #>  Observation noise variance (V): #>   2.0543e+04 #>  #> Initial states (m0): #>   fourier(12): -7.2510e+02 #>   fourier(12): -7.4524e+02 #>   fourier(12):  4.1713e+02 #>   fourier(12):  8.1375e+01 #>   fourier(12):  1.5506e+02 #>   fourier(12): -1.9470e+02 #>   fourier(12): -1.0038e+01 #>   fourier(12):  1.5899e+02 #>   fourier(12):  1.5997e+02 #>   fourier(12):  2.0428e+02 #>   fourier(12): -1.5165e+01 #>   trend(1):  9.7398e+03 elec_tr <- tsibbledata::vic_elec |>   filter(     Time < lubridate::ymd("2012-03-01")   ) |>    mutate(WorkDay = wday(Time) %in% 2:6 & !Holiday)  elec_fit <- elec_tr |>   model(     fasster = fasster(log(Demand) ~        WorkDay %S% (fourier(48, 16) + trend(1)) + Temperature + I(Temperature^2)     )   )

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend, and Exogenous Regressors
text: Fitted FASSTER models can decomposed provide description underlying states function. Decomposing FASSTER model provides aggregates components trends seasonalities. components can accessed fitted model using components() function: tools made available fasster designed integrate seamlessly tidyverse packages, enabling familiar data manipulation visualisation capabilities.
code: fit |>    components() #> # A dable: 72 x 5 [1M] #> # Key:     .model [1] #> # :        value = `fourier(12)` + `trend(1)` #>    .model     index value `fourier(12)` `trend(1)` #>    <chr>      <mth> <dbl>         <dbl>      <dbl> #>  1 fasster 1973 Jan  9007        -795.       9740. #>  2 fasster 1973 Feb  8106       -1546.       9754. #>  3 fasster 1973 Mar  8928        -758.       9719. #>  4 fasster 1973 Apr  9137        -536.       9706. #>  5 fasster 1973 May 10017         322.       9693. #>  6 fasster 1973 Jun 10826         802.       9694. #>  7 fasster 1973 Jul 11317        1669.       9830. #>  8 fasster 1973 Aug 10744         974.       9755. #>  9 fasster 1973 Sep  9713         -65.7      9761. #> 10 fasster 1973 Oct  9938         233.       9768. #> # ℹ 62 more rows elec_fit |>   components() #> # A dable: 2,880 x 9 [30m] <Australia/Melbourne> #> # Key:     .model [1] #> # :        log(Demand) = `WorkDay_FALSE/fourier(48, 16)` + #> #   `WorkDay_FALSE/trend(1)` + `WorkDay_TRUE/fourier(48, 16)` + #> #   `WorkDay_TRUE/trend(1)` + Temperature + `I(Temperature^2)` #>    .model  Time                `log(Demand)` `WorkDay_FALSE/fourier(48, 16)` #>    <chr>   <dttm>                      <dbl>                           <dbl> #>  1 fasster 2012-01-01 00:00:00          8.39                        -0.00345 #>  2 fasster 2012-01-01 00:30:00          8.36                        -0.0234  #>  3 fasster 2012-01-01 01:00:00          8.31                        -0.0971  #>  4 fasster 2012-01-01 01:30:00          8.26                        -0.105   #>  5 fasster 2012-01-01 02:00:00          8.30                        -0.117   #>  6 fasster 2012-01-01 02:30:00          8.26                        -0.0812  #>  7 fasster 2012-01-01 03:00:00          8.21                        -0.251   #>  8 fasster 2012-01-01 03:30:00          8.18                        -0.144   #>  9 fasster 2012-01-01 04:00:00          8.14                        -0.374   #> 10 fasster 2012-01-01 04:30:00          8.12                        -0.202   #> # ℹ 2,870 more rows #> # ℹ 5 more variables: `WorkDay_FALSE/trend(1)` <dbl>, #> #   `WorkDay_TRUE/fourier(48, 16)` <dbl>, `WorkDay_TRUE/trend(1)` <dbl>, #> #   Temperature <dbl>, `I(Temperature^2)` <dbl>

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend, and Exogenous Regressors
text: fasster conforms object structure fable package, allowing common visualisation analysis tools applied FASSTER models.  Future index values automatically produced used necessary model specification. additional information required model (WorkDay Temperature) must included tsibble future values passed new_data.
code: fit |>    forecast(h=24) |>   autoplot(as_tsibble(USAccDeaths)) elec_ts <- tsibbledata::vic_elec |>   filter(     yearmonth(Time) == yearmonth("2012 Mar")   ) |>    mutate(WorkDay = wday(Time) %in% 2:6 & !Holiday) |>    select(-Demand) elec_fit |>    forecast(new_data = elec_ts) |>    autoplot(elec_tr)

what: Extract Components from a FASSTER Model — components.FASSTER
title: Extract Components from a FASSTER Model — components.FASSTER
text: Decomposes FASSTER model individual components, allowing examine contribution term fitted values. useful understanding components drive model's predictions well different aspects model fit data.

title: Extract Components from a FASSTER Model — components.FASSTER
code: # S3 method for class 'FASSTER' components(object, ...)

title: Extract Components from a FASSTER Model — components.FASSTER
text: object FASSTER model object. ... Additional arguments (currently unused).

title: Extract Components from a FASSTER Model — components.FASSTER
text: dable (decomposition table) containing response variable model component separate columns. components sum response variable.

title: Extract Components from a FASSTER Model — components.FASSTER
code: if (requireNamespace("tsibbledata", quietly = TRUE)) { # Fit a FASSTER model and extract components library(tsibble) library(dplyr) fit <- tsibbledata::aus_retail |>   filter(     State == "Victoria",     Industry == "Cafes, restaurants and catering services"   ) |>   model(fasster = FASSTER(Turnover ~ trend(1) + season("year")))  # Extract and view components components(fit) } #>  #> Attaching package: ‘tsibble’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, union #>  #> Attaching package: ‘dplyr’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union #> # A dable: 441 x 7 [1M] #> # Key:     State, Industry, .model [1] #> # :        Turnover = `season("year")` + `trend(1)` #>    State    Industry        .model    Month Turnover `season("year")` `trend(1)` #>    <chr>    <chr>           <chr>     <mth>    <dbl>            <dbl>      <dbl> #>  1 Victoria Cafes, restaur… fasst… 1982 Apr     36.4           -2.08        37.9 #>  2 Victoria Cafes, restaur… fasst… 1982 May     36.2           -2.01        38.1 #>  3 Victoria Cafes, restaur… fasst… 1982 Jun     35.7           -1.95        38.2 #>  4 Victoria Cafes, restaur… fasst… 1982 Jul     34.6           -1.39        37.9 #>  5 Victoria Cafes, restaur… fasst… 1982 Aug     32.5           -1.46        37.1 #>  6 Victoria Cafes, restaur… fasst… 1982 Sep     33.9           -0.799       35.7 #>  7 Victoria Cafes, restaur… fasst… 1982 Oct     37.7            1.95        35.2 #>  8 Victoria Cafes, restaur… fasst… 1982 Nov     40.3            3.81        35.5 #>  9 Victoria Cafes, restaur… fasst… 1982 Dec     45.2            8.71        35.9 #> 10 Victoria Cafes, restaur… fasst… 1983 Jan     36.9           -1.38        36.2 #> # ℹ 431 more rows

what: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
text: Implements FASSTER

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
code: FASSTER(formula, include = NULL, ...)

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
text: formula object class "formula" (refer 'Specials' section usage) include many terms included fit model ... used

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
text: Returns mable containing fitted FASSTER model.

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
text: fasster model extends commonly used state space models introducing switching component measurement equation. implemented using time-varying DLM switching behaviour encoded measurement matrix.

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
text: specials define model structure FASSTER. model can include trend, seasonal, ARMA, exogenous regressor components, optional switching behaviour controlled grouping factors.

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
text: trend special specifies polynomial trend components.
code: trend(n, ...)

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
text: season special specifies seasonal factors using indicator variables.
code: season(period = NULL, ...)

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
text: fourier special specifies seasonal components using Fourier terms (trigonometric functions).
code: fourier(period = NULL, K = floor(period/2), ...)

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
text: ARMA special includes autoregressive moving average components.
code: ARMA(...)

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
text: xreg special includes exogenous regressors model.
code: xreg(...)

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
text: custom special allows specify custom DLM structures.
code: custom(...)

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
text: %S% operator creates switching models different model structures apply different groups defined factor variable. example, group %S% trend(1) creates separate level value group, allowing mean switch groups.
code: group

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
text: %?% operator creates conditional models component active logical condition TRUE. example, (year > 2000) %?% trend(1) includes level component observations 2000.
code: condition

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
text: model parameters estimated using following heuristic: Filter data using specified model non-zero state variances Obtain smoothed states \((\theta^{(s)}t=\theta_t|D_T)\) approximate correct behaviour initial state parameters taken first smoothed state: \(m_0=E(\theta^{(s)}_0)\), \(C_0=Var(\theta^{(s)}_0)\) Obtain state noise variances smoothed variance \(w_t\): \(W=Var(w^{(s)}_t)=Var(\theta^{(s)}_t-G\theta^{(s)}_{t-1})\) Obtain measurement noise variance smoothed variance \(v_t\): \(V=Var(v^{(s)}_t)=Var(y_t-F_t\theta^{(s)}_t)\) Repair restricted state variances seasonal factors ARMA terms

title: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend and Exogenous Regressors — FASSTER
code: # Basic model with trend and seasonality cbind(mdeaths, fdeaths) |>   as_tsibble(pivot_longer = FALSE) |>   model(FASSTER(mdeaths ~ trend(1) + fourier(12))) #> # A mable: 1 x 1 #>   `FASSTER(mdeaths ~ trend(1) + fourier(12))` #>                                       <model> #> 1                                   <FASSTER>  # Model with exogenous regressor cbind(mdeaths, fdeaths) |>   as_tsibble(pivot_longer = FALSE) |>   model(FASSTER(mdeaths ~ fdeaths + trend(1) + fourier(12))) #> # A mable: 1 x 1 #>   `FASSTER(mdeaths ~ fdeaths + trend(1) + fourier(12))` #>                                                 <model> #> 1                                             <FASSTER>  # Switching model with different trends for different periods cbind(mdeaths, fdeaths) |>   as_tsibble(pivot_longer = FALSE) |>   model(     FASSTER(mdeaths ~ (lubridate::year(index) > 1977) %S% trend(1) + fourier(12))   ) #> # A mable: 1 x 1 #>   FASSTER(mdeaths ~ (lubridate::year(index) > 1977) %S% trend(1) + \n    fouri…¹ #>                                                                          <model> #> 1                                                                      <FASSTER> #> # ℹ abbreviated name: #> #   ¹​`FASSTER(mdeaths ~ (lubridate::year(index) > 1977) %S% trend(1) + \n    fourier(12))`

what: fasster: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend, and Exogenous Regressors — fasster-package
title: fasster: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend, and Exogenous Regressors — fasster-package
text: Implementation FASSTER (Forecasting Additive Switching Seasonality, Trend, Exogenous Regressors) model forecasting time series multiple seasonal patterns. model combines state space methodology switching component observation equation allow flexible modeling complex seasonal patterns, including time-varying effects multiple seasonalities.

title: fasster: Fast Additive Switching of Seasonality, Trend, and Exogenous Regressors — fasster-package
text: Maintainer: Mitchell O'Hara-Wild mail@mitchelloharawild.com Authors: Rob Hyndman [thesis advisor]

what: Extract fitted values from a FASSTER model — fitted.FASSTER
title: Extract fitted values from a FASSTER model — fitted.FASSTER
text: Returns one-step-ahead fitted values FASSTER model, calculated Kalman filtering process. represent model's predictions time point using information available point.

title: Extract fitted values from a FASSTER model — fitted.FASSTER
code: # S3 method for class 'FASSTER' fitted(object, ...)

title: Extract fitted values from a FASSTER model — fitted.FASSTER
code: library(tsibble) fit <- as_tsibble(mdeaths) |>   model(FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)))  # Extract fitted values fitted(fit) #> # A tsibble: 72 x 3 [1M] #> # Key:       .model [1] #>    .model                                     index .fitted #>    <chr>                                      <mth>   <dbl> #>  1 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Jan   2084. #>  2 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Feb   2047. #>  3 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Mar   1896. #>  4 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Apr   1581. #>  5 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 May   1335. #>  6 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Jun   1262. #>  7 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Jul   1211. #>  8 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Aug   1139. #>  9 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Sep   1124. #> 10 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Oct   1376. #> # ℹ 62 more rows

title: Forecast a FASSTER model — forecast.FASSTER
text: Produces forecasts trained FASSTER model using Kalman filter framework. method generates point forecasts prediction intervals propagating state space forward time.

title: Forecast a FASSTER model — forecast.FASSTER
code: # S3 method for class 'FASSTER' forecast(object, new_data, specials = NULL, ...)

title: Forecast a FASSTER model — forecast.FASSTER
text: object trained FASSTER model object. new_data tsibble containing future time points forecast. Must regularly spaced contain required exogenous regressors. specials list special formulations generated model formula, used construct design matrix time-varying components. ... Additional arguments (currently unused).

title: Forecast a FASSTER model — forecast.FASSTER
text: distribution vector (distributional package) containing normal distributions forecasted means standard errors future time point. integrates fable's forecast distribution structure.

title: Forecast a FASSTER model — forecast.FASSTER
text: forecast method implements Kalman filter propagate state space model forward time: forecast horizon, constructs time-varying system matrices (FF, GG, V, W) using exogenous variables new_data Computes state forecast: \(a_{t+1} = G_t a_t\) Computes state covariance: \(R_{t+1} = G_t R_t G_t' + W_t\) Computes observation forecast: \(f_t = F_t a_{t+1}\) Computes forecast variance: \(Q_t = F_t R_{t+1} F_t' + V_t\) method handles switching components matching exogenous variables new_data model's design matrix, adding zero columns missing levels.

what: Glance at a FASSTER model — glance.FASSTER
title: Glance at a FASSTER model — glance.FASSTER
text: Constructs single-row summary model's goodness--fit statistics. method follows broom package conventions used fabletools provide model selection metrics.

title: Glance at a FASSTER model — glance.FASSTER
code: # S3 method for class 'FASSTER' glance(x, ...)

title: Glance at a FASSTER model — glance.FASSTER
text: x FASSTER model object. ... Additional arguments (currently unused).

title: Glance at a FASSTER model — glance.FASSTER
text: one-row tibble containing: sigma2 estimated observation variance (V). model multivariate observations, list containing variance matrix. log_lik log-likelihood model. AIC Akaike Information Criterion. AICc Corrected AIC small sample sizes. BIC Bayesian Information Criterion.

title: Glance at a FASSTER model — glance.FASSTER
code: library(tsibble) fit <- as_tsibble(mdeaths) |>   model(FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)))  # Get model fit statistics glance(fit) #> # A tibble: 1 × 6 #>   .model                                  sigma2 log_lik   AIC  AICc   BIC #>   <chr>                                    <dbl>   <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 11359.    409.  842.  848.  870.

what: Interpolate missing values in a FASSTER model — interpolate.FASSTER
title: Interpolate missing values in a FASSTER model — interpolate.FASSTER
text: Fills missing values response variable using model's fitted values. method works interpolating data used estimate model used new data.

title: Interpolate missing values in a FASSTER model — interpolate.FASSTER
code: # S3 method for class 'FASSTER' interpolate(object, new_data, specials, ...)

title: Interpolate missing values in a FASSTER model — interpolate.FASSTER
text: object fitted FASSTER model object. new_data tsibble containing data interpolate. Must data used fit model. specials list special terms (passed fabletools). ... Additional arguments (currently unused).

title: Interpolate missing values in a FASSTER model — interpolate.FASSTER
text: tsibble missing values response variable replaced fitted values.

title: Interpolate missing values in a FASSTER model — interpolate.FASSTER
text: method identifies missing values (NAs) response variable replaces corresponding fitted values model. works new_data length data used fit model.

title: Interpolate missing values in a FASSTER model — interpolate.FASSTER
code: library(tsibble) library(dplyr)  # Create data with missing values deaths_na <- as_tsibble(mdeaths) |>   mutate(value = if_else(row_number() %in% c(10, 20, 30), NA_real_, value))  # Fit model fit <- deaths_na |>   model(FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)))  # Interpolate missing values interpolate(fit, deaths_na) #> # A tsibble: 72 x 2 [1M] #>       index value #>       <mth> <dbl> #>  1 1974 Jan 2134  #>  2 1974 Feb 1863  #>  3 1974 Mar 1877  #>  4 1974 Apr 1877  #>  5 1974 May 1492  #>  6 1974 Jun 1249  #>  7 1974 Jul 1280  #>  8 1974 Aug 1131  #>  9 1974 Sep 1209  #> 10 1974 Oct 1355. #> # ℹ 62 more rows

title: Refit a FASSTER model — refit.FASSTER
text: Applies fitted FASSTER model new dataset.

title: Refit a FASSTER model — refit.FASSTER
code: # S3 method for class 'FASSTER' refit(object, new_data, specials = NULL, reestimate = FALSE, ...)

title: Refit a FASSTER model — refit.FASSTER
text: object fitted FASSTER model. new_data tsibble containing new data. specials (passed fabletools::refit.mdl_df()). reestimate TRUE, model parameters re-estimated suit new data using heuristic approach. FALSE, existing model structure parameters applied new data without modification. ... Additional arguments passed training function.

title: Refit a FASSTER model — refit.FASSTER
text: refitted FASSTER model.

title: Refit a FASSTER model — refit.FASSTER
code: library(tsibble)  # Fit model to male deaths fit_male <- as_tsibble(mdeaths) |>   model(FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)))  # Refit to female deaths without re-estimating parameters refit(fit_male, as_tsibble(fdeaths), reestimate = FALSE) #> # A mable: 1 x 1 #>   `FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12))` #>                                     <model> #> 1                                 <FASSTER>  # Refit to female deaths with re-estimated parameters refit(fit_male, as_tsibble(fdeaths), reestimate = TRUE) #> # A mable: 1 x 1 #>   `FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12))` #>                                     <model> #> 1                                 <FASSTER>

what: Report on a FASSTER model — report.FASSTER
title: Report on a FASSTER model — report.FASSTER
text: Prints detailed report estimated variance parameters FASSTER model. includes state noise variances (W) model component observation noise variance (V).

title: Report on a FASSTER model — report.FASSTER
code: # S3 method for class 'FASSTER' report(object, ...)

title: Report on a FASSTER model — report.FASSTER
text: object FASSTER model object. ... Additional arguments (currently unused).

title: Report on a FASSTER model — report.FASSTER
text: Invisibly returns NULL. Called side effect printing variance report console.

title: Report on a FASSTER model — report.FASSTER
text: report displays: State noise variances (W): variance random innovations state component, grouped model term. Observation noise variance (V): variance measurement error.

title: Report on a FASSTER model — report.FASSTER
code: library(tsibble) fit <- as_tsibble(mdeaths) |>   model(FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)))  # Print variance report report(fit) #> Series: value  #> Model: FASSTER  #>  #> Estimated variances: #>  State noise variances (W): #>   fourier(12) #>    5.8919e-15 9.9142e-15 1.0420e-14 2.5508e-14 4.4283e-14 3.0217e-14 3.1047e-14 2.6410e-14 2.8499e-14 4.3367e-14 9.1290e-15 #>   trend(1) #>    1.9118e+03 #>  #>  Observation noise variance (V): #>   1.1359e+04 #>  #> Initial states (m0): #>   fourier(12):  3.1018e+02 #>   fourier(12):  4.3228e+02 #>   fourier(12): -2.6396e+00 #>   fourier(12):  1.0825e+02 #>   fourier(12):  7.9098e-01 #>   fourier(12): -6.9576e+00 #>   fourier(12):  1.6938e+00 #>   fourier(12):  4.8947e+01 #>   fourier(12):  5.1493e+00 #>   fourier(12):  2.3894e+01 #>   fourier(12):  6.0760e+00 #>   trend(1):  1.4712e+03

code: library(tsibble) fit <- as_tsibble(mdeaths) |>   model(FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)))  # Extract residuals residuals(fit) #> # A tsibble: 72 x 3 [1M] #> # Key:       .model [1] #>    .model                                     index  .resid #>    <chr>                                      <mth>   <dbl> #>  1 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Jan   49.6  #>  2 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Feb -184.   #>  3 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Mar  -19.0  #>  4 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Apr  296.   #>  5 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 May  157.   #>  6 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Jun  -13.2  #>  7 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Jul   68.6  #>  8 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Aug   -8.01 #>  9 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Sep   84.9  #> 10 FASSTER(value ~ trend(1) + fourier(12)) 1974 Oct  116.   #> # ℹ 62 more rows

what: Stream new data through a FASSTER model — stream.FASSTER
title: Stream new data through a FASSTER model — stream.FASSTER
text: Extends fitted FASSTER model filtering new observations existing state space model. model's states parameters updated sequentially new data arrives, allowing online learning without refitting scratch.

title: Stream new data through a FASSTER model — stream.FASSTER
code: # S3 method for class 'FASSTER' stream(object, new_data, specials = NULL, ...)

title: Stream new data through a FASSTER model — stream.FASSTER
text: object fitted FASSTER model object new_data tsibble containing new observations stream model specials list special terms (switching variables, etc.) parsed model formula ... Additional arguments (currently unused)

title: Stream new data through a FASSTER model — stream.FASSTER
text: updated FASSTER model object : Extended state estimates incorporating new data Updated model variance Appended fitted values residuals Updated DLM components future forecasting

title: Stream new data through a FASSTER model — stream.FASSTER
text: streaming process: Constructs design matrix new data Applies Kalman filter sequentially update states Updates model variance based residuals Prepares model subsequent forecasting streaming

title: Stream new data through a FASSTER model — stream.FASSTER
code: library(tsibble) library(fasster)  # Fit initial model on training data fit <- as_tsibble(head(USAccDeaths, -12)) |>   model(fasster = FASSTER(value ~ trend() + season("year"))) tidy(fit) #> # A tibble: 13 × 4 #>    .model  term               estimate std.error #>    <chr>   <chr>                 <dbl>     <dbl> #>  1 fasster "season(\"year\")"   -167.       1.91 #>  2 fasster "season(\"year\")"   -215.       1.92 #>  3 fasster "season(\"year\")"    278.       1.92 #>  4 fasster "season(\"year\")"    -64.0      1.91 #>  5 fasster "season(\"year\")"    991.       1.92 #>  6 fasster "season(\"year\")"   1515.       1.92 #>  7 fasster "season(\"year\")"    988.       1.92 #>  8 fasster "season(\"year\")"    264.       1.92 #>  9 fasster "season(\"year\")"   -488.       1.91 #> 10 fasster "season(\"year\")"   -695.       1.91 #> 11 fasster "season(\"year\")"  -1593.       1.93 #> 12 fasster "trend()"            9830.       2.92 #> 13 fasster "trend()"             -59.7      1.52 tail(fitted(fit), 20) #> # A tsibble: 20 x 3 [1M] #> # Key:       .model [1] #>    .model     index .fitted #>    <chr>      <mth>   <dbl> #>  1 fasster 1976 May   9187. #>  2 fasster 1976 Jun   9240. #>  3 fasster 1976 Jul   9513. #>  4 fasster 1976 Aug   9305. #>  5 fasster 1976 Sep   8052. #>  6 fasster 1976 Oct   8263. #>  7 fasster 1976 Nov   7973. #>  8 fasster 1976 Dec   7769. #>  9 fasster 1977 Jan   7774. #> 10 fasster 1977 Feb   7483. #> 11 fasster 1977 Mar   7870. #> 12 fasster 1977 Apr   7974. #> 13 fasster 1977 May   9014. #> 14 fasster 1977 Jun   9382. #> 15 fasster 1977 Jul  10268. #> 16 fasster 1977 Aug   9798. #> 17 fasster 1977 Sep   8430. #> 18 fasster 1977 Oct   8651. #> 19 fasster 1977 Nov   8109. #> 20 fasster 1977 Dec   8541.  # Stream new data through the model fit_updated <- fit |>   stream(as_tsibble(tail(USAccDeaths, 12))) tidy(fit_updated) #> # A tibble: 13 × 4 #>    .model  term               estimate std.error #>    <chr>   <chr>                 <dbl>     <dbl> #>  1 fasster "season(\"year\")"   -167.       1.91 #>  2 fasster "season(\"year\")"   -215.       1.92 #>  3 fasster "season(\"year\")"    278.       1.92 #>  4 fasster "season(\"year\")"    -64.0      1.91 #>  5 fasster "season(\"year\")"    991.       1.92 #>  6 fasster "season(\"year\")"   1515.       1.92 #>  7 fasster "season(\"year\")"    988.       1.92 #>  8 fasster "season(\"year\")"    264.       1.92 #>  9 fasster "season(\"year\")"   -488.       1.91 #> 10 fasster "season(\"year\")"   -695.       1.91 #> 11 fasster "season(\"year\")"  -1593.       1.93 #> 12 fasster "trend()"            9830.       2.92 #> 13 fasster "trend()"             -59.7      1.52 tail(fitted(fit_updated), 20) #> # A tsibble: 20 x 3 [1M] #> # Key:       .model [1] #>    .model     index .fitted #>    <chr>      <mth>   <dbl> #>  1 fasster 1977 May   9014. #>  2 fasster 1977 Jun   9382. #>  3 fasster 1977 Jul  10268. #>  4 fasster 1977 Aug   9798. #>  5 fasster 1977 Sep   8430. #>  6 fasster 1977 Oct   8651. #>  7 fasster 1977 Nov   8109. #>  8 fasster 1977 Dec   8541. #>  9 fasster 1978 Jan   7963. #> 10 fasster 1978 Feb   7300. #> 11 fasster 1978 Mar   7756. #> 12 fasster 1978 Apr   8058. #> 13 fasster 1978 May   8996. #> 14 fasster 1978 Jun   9494. #> 15 fasster 1978 Jul  10666. #> 16 fasster 1978 Aug   9504. #> 17 fasster 1978 Sep   8721. #> 18 fasster 1978 Oct   9493. #> 19 fasster 1978 Nov   8656. #> 20 fasster 1978 Dec   9035.

what: Extract coefficients from a FASSTER model — tidy.FASSTER
title: Extract coefficients from a FASSTER model — tidy.FASSTER
text: Obtains mean variance estimated initial states FASSTER model. Values estimate column contains mean, std.error column contains standard deviation initial states.

title: Extract coefficients from a FASSTER model — tidy.FASSTER
code: # S3 method for class 'FASSTER' tidy(x, ...)

title: Extract coefficients from a FASSTER model — tidy.FASSTER
text: x object containing FASSTER model. ... Unused.

title: Extract coefficients from a FASSTER model — tidy.FASSTER
text: tibble three columns: term name state variable model. estimate mean estimated initial state term. std.error standard deviation estimated initial state term.

title: fasster 0.2.0
text: Fast Additive Switching Seasonality, Trend Exogenous Regressors (FASSTER) state space model designed forecasting time series multiple seasonal patterns. model extends traditional state space models introducing switching component measurement equation, enabling flexible modeling complex seasonal patterns, time series dynamics rapid structural changes. FASSTER model implementation: Model specification: Flexible formula interface supporting: trend() polynomial trends season() seasonal factors fourier() trigonometric seasonal terms ARMA() autoregressive moving average components xreg() exogenous regressors %S% switching operator group-specific model structures %?% conditional operator time-varying components Model methods: Full integration fable framework: fitted() residuals() model diagnostics augment() augmenting data model estimates tidy() extracting coefficients (initial state estimates) glance() model summary statistics (AIC, BIC, log-likelihood) report() displaying estimated state observation variances components() decomposing fitted values trend seasonal components forecast() generating predictions interpolate() filling missing values refit() applying fitted model new data optional re-estimation stream() extending models new observations Heuristic estimation: Model parameters estimated using heuristic approach based filtering smoothing obtain initial state parameters variance estimates.
